statement.p: Find a vector equation for the line in the direction of \vec{v}=2\vec{i} +2\vec{j} -\vec{k} passing through the point (2,2,2).

hint.p: Recall that a vector equation for a line passing through point P at t=0 in the direction of the vector \vec{v} is \vec{r}(t)=\vec{P} +\vec{v}t where \vec{P} is the position vector with head at point P.

solution.p: A vector equation for the line in the direction of \vec{v}=2\vec{i} +2\vec{j} -\vec{k} passing through the point P=(2,2,2) at t=0 is \[\vec{r}(t)=\vec{P}+t\vec{v},\] where \vec{P} is the position vector with head at point P. Thus we get \vec{r}(t)\amp =2\vec{i}+2\vec{j}+2\vec{k}+t(2\vec{i} +2\vec{j} -\vec{k}) \amp =(2+2t)\vec{i} +(2+2t)\vec{j} +(2-t)\vec{k}.

statement.p: Find a vector equation for the line in the direction of \vec{v}=2\vec{i} +2\vec{j} -\vec{k} passing through the point (2,2,2)\text{.}

hint.p: Recall that a vector equation for a line passing through point P at t=0 in the direction of the vector \vec{v} is \vec{r}(t)=\vec{P} +\vec{v}t where \vec{P} is the position vector with head at point P\text{.}

solution.p: A vector equation for the line in the direction of \vec{v}=2\vec{i} +2\vec{j} -\vec{k} passing through the point P=(2,2,2) at t=0 is \[\vec{r}(t)=\vec{P}+t\vec{v},\] where \vec{P} is the position vector with head at point P\text{.} Thus we get

statement.p: Find a vector equation for the line segment from (1,2,3) to (3,2,1).
\vec{r}(t) = for \leq t \leq

hint.p: Recall that a vector equation for a line segment from point P to point Q is \vec{r}(t)=\vec{P} +\vec{PQ}t for 0\leq t\leq 1 where \vec{P} is the position vector with head at point P and \vec{PQ} is the vector pointing from P to Q.

statement.p: Find a vector equation for the line segment from (1,2,3) to (3,2,1)\text{.}
\vec{r}(t) = for \leq t \leq

hint.p: Recall that a vector equation for a line segment from point P to point Q is \vec{r}(t)=\vec{P} +\vec{PQ}t for 0\leq t\leq 1 where \vec{P} is the position vector with head at point P and \vec{PQ} is the vector pointing from P to Q\text{.}

solution.p: The vector pointing from (1,2,3) to (3,2,1) is \vec{v}=2\vec{i} -2\vec{k}\text{.} Therefore, a vector equation for this line segment will be
with 0\leq t\leq 1\text{.}

statement.p: Find a vector equation for a quarter circle centered at (0,0) of radius 3 starting at the point (3,0) and oriented counter-clockwise.
for \leq t \leq

hint.p: Recall that \vec{r}(t) =\cos t \vec{i} +\sin t \vec{j}, 0\leq t\leq 2\pi gives a full circle oriented counter-clockwise starting (when t=0) at (1,0).

solution.p: The equation \vec{r}(t) =\cos t \vec{i} +\sin t \vec{j}, 0\leq t\leq 2\pi gives a full circle of radius 1 oriented counter-clockwise starting at (1,0) when t=0. To get a circle of radius 3, we scale each component by 3. Thus \vec{r}(t) =3\cos t \vec{i} +3\sin t \vec{j} for 0\leq t\leq 2\pi is a circle of radius 3 centered at (0,0) oriented counterclockwise starting at (0,3) when t=0. To get the quarter circle, we restrict 0\leq t\leq \pi/2.

statement.p: Find a vector equation for a quarter circle centered at (0,0) of radius 3 starting at the point (3,0) and oriented counter-clockwise.
for \leq t \leq

hint.p: Recall that \vec{r}(t) =\cos t \vec{i} +\sin t \vec{j}\text{,} 0\leq t\leq 2\pi gives a full circle oriented counter-clockwise starting (when t=0) at (1,0)\text{.}

solution.p: The equation \vec{r}(t) =\cos t \vec{i} +\sin t \vec{j}\text{,} 0\leq t\leq 2\pi gives a full circle of radius 1 oriented counter-clockwise starting at (1,0) when t=0\text{.} To get a circle of radius 3\text{,} we scale each component by 3\text{.} Thus \vec{r}(t) =3\cos t \vec{i} +3\sin t \vec{j} for 0\leq t\leq 2\pi is a circle of radius 3 centered at (0,0) oriented counterclockwise starting at (0,3) when t=0\text{.} To get the quarter circle, we restrict 0\leq t\leq \pi/2\text{.}

statement.p: Find a vector equation for a half circle centered at (1,4,1) of radius 2 in the plane y=4 starting at the point (3,4,1).
for \leq t \leq

hint.p: The equation \vec{r}(t) =\cos t \vec{i} +\sin t \vec{k}, 0\leq t\leq 2\pi gives a full circle oriented counter-clockwise starting (when t=0) at (1,0) in the xz-plane. How can you modify this vector equation to give the described circle?

statement.p: Find a vector equation for a half circle centered at (1,4,1) of radius 2 in the plane y=4 starting at the point (3,4,1)\text{.}
for \leq t \leq

hint.p: The equation \vec{r}(t) =\cos t \vec{i} +\sin t \vec{k}\text{,} 0\leq t\leq 2\pi gives a full circle oriented counter-clockwise starting (when t=0) at (1,0) in the xz-plane. How can you modify this vector equation to give the described circle?

solution.p: The equation \vec{r}(t) =\cos t \vec{i} +\sin t \vec{k}\text{,} 0\leq t\leq 2\pi gives a full circle oriented counter-clockwise starting (when t=0) at (1,0,0) in the xz-plane. To get a circle of radius 2\text{,} we scale each component by 2\text{,} and to move the center to (1,4,1) we add the vector \vec{i} +4\vec{j}+\vec{k} (which translates every point in the x-direction by 1\text{,} the y-direction by 4 and the z-direction by 1). Thus
for 0\leq t\leq 2\pi is a circle of radius 2 centered at (1,4,1) in the plane y=4 starting at the point (3,2,1)\text{.} To get the half circle, we restrict 0\leq t\leq \pi\text{.}

statement.p: Find a vector equation for a spiral starting at (5,0,0) rotating and moving up the z-axis with z=t, a rotation speed of one revolution per each vertical unit of displacement, and with radius 5 oriented counterclockwise when view from above.
\vec{r}(t)= for t\geq

hint.p: Recall that \vec{r}(t) =\cos t \vec{i} +\sin t \vec{j} parameterizes a circle of radius 1 in the xy-plane centered at (0,0) oriented counter-clockwise when viewed from above starting (when t=0) at (1,0). How can you modify this equation to get the described spiral?

solution.p: The equation \vec{r}(t) =\cos t \vec{i} +\sin t \vec{j} gives a circle of radius 1 in the xy-plane oriented counter-clockwise when viewed from above and centered at (0,0) starting (when t=0) at (1,0). To get a circle of radius 5 with starting point (5,0), we scale each component by 5, and to make the curve spiral around the z-axis, we add the component t\vec{k}. Thus \vec{r}(t)=5\cos(t)\vec{i} + 5\sin(t)\vec{j}+t\vec{k} is a vector equation for the described curve.

statement.p: Find a vector equation for a spiral starting at (5,0,0) rotating and moving up the z-axis with z=t\text{,} a rotation speed of one revolution per each vertical unit of displacement, and with radius 5 oriented counterclockwise when view from above.
\vec{r}(t)= for t\geq

hint.p: Recall that \vec{r}(t) =\cos t \vec{i} +\sin t \vec{j} parameterizes a circle of radius 1 in the xy-plane centered at (0,0) oriented counter-clockwise when viewed from above starting (when t=0) at (1,0)\text{.} How can you modify this equation to get the described spiral?

solution.p: The equation \vec{r}(t) =\cos t \vec{i} +\sin t \vec{j} gives a circle of radius 1 in the xy-plane oriented counter-clockwise when viewed from above and centered at (0,0) starting (when t=0) at (1,0)\text{.} To get a circle of radius 5 with starting point (5,0)\text{,} we scale each component by 5\text{,} and to make the curve spiral around the z-axis, we add the component t\vec{k}\text{.} Thus \vec{r}(t)=5\cos(t)\vec{i} + 5\sin(t)\vec{j}+t\vec{k} is a vector equation for the described curve.

statement.p: Find a vector equation for the segment of the graph of y=x^3 starting at (2,8) to the point (-1,-1).
for \leq t \leq

hint.p: Recall that to parameterize a curve that follows that graph of a function y=f(x) oriented from right to left, we can choose x=-t and then y is completely determined by the function y=f(x).

solution.p: To parameterize a curve that follows that graph of a function y=f(x) oriented from right to left, we can choose x=-t and then we get y=f(-t)=-t^3. Thus, \vec{r}(t) =-t\vec{i} -t^3\vec{j} is a vector equation for y=x^3 oriented from right to left. Since x=-t we choose -2\leq t\leq 1 to restrict to the appropriate domain.

statement.p: Find a vector equation for the segment of the graph of y=x^3 starting at (2,8) to the point (-1,-1)\text{.}
for \leq t \leq

hint.p: Recall that to parameterize a curve that follows that graph of a function y=f(x) oriented from right to left, we can choose x=-t and then y is completely determined by the function y=f(x)\text{.}

solution.p: To parameterize a curve that follows that graph of a function y=f(x) oriented from right to left, we can choose x=-t and then we get y=f(-t)=-t^3\text{.} Thus, \vec{r}(t) =-t\vec{i} -t^3\vec{j} is a vector equation for y=x^3 oriented from right to left. Since x=-t we choose -2\leq t\leq 1 to restrict to the appropriate domain.

statement.p: Find \vec{r}'(t) for \vec{r}(t)=t^2\vec{i}-\sin t\vec{j} +e^{ t}\vec{k}.

hint.p: The components of \vec{r}'(t) are the derivatives of the components of \vec{r}(t), so use standard single variable rules to differentiate each component.

solution.p: The components of \vec{r}'(t) are the derivatives of the components of \vec{r}(t). Thus, \vec{r}'(t)=2t\vec{i}-\cos t\vec{j} + e^{ t}\vec{k}.

statement.p: Find \vec{r}'(t) for \vec{r}(t)=t^2\vec{i}-\sin t\vec{j} +e^{{24} t}\vec{k}\text{.}

hint.p: The components of \vec{r}'(t) are the derivatives of the components of \vec{r}(t)\text{,} so use standard single variable rules to differentiate each component.

solution.p: The components of \vec{r}'(t) are the derivatives of the components of \vec{r}(t)\text{.} Thus, \vec{r}'(t)=2t\vec{i}-\cos t\vec{j} +{24} e^{{24} t}\vec{k}\text{.}

statement.p: Find \vec{r}'(t) for \vec{r}(t)=\cos t \vec{i}+\sin t\vec{j} +\ln( t)\vec{k}.

hint.p: The components of \vec{r}'(t) are the derivatives of the components of \vec{r}(t), so use standard single variable rules to differentiate each component.

solution.p: The components of \vec{r}'(t) are the derivatives of the components of \vec{r}(t). Thus, \vec{r}'(t)=\displaystyle -\sin t \vec{i}+\cos t\vec{j} +\frac{1}{t} \vec{k}.

statement.p: Find \vec{r}'(t) for \vec{r}(t)=\cos t \vec{i}+\sin t\vec{j} +\ln({27} t)\vec{k}\text{.}

hint.p: The components of \vec{r}'(t) are the derivatives of the components of \vec{r}(t)\text{,} so use standard single variable rules to differentiate each component.

solution.p: The components of \vec{r}'(t) are the derivatives of the components of \vec{r}(t)\text{.} Thus, \vec{r}'(t)=\displaystyle -\sin t \vec{i}+\cos t\vec{j} +\frac{1}{t} \vec{k}\text{.}

statement.p: Find \vec{F} (\vec{r}(t)) for \vec{F} (x,y)=- y\vec{i} + x\vec{j} and \vec{r}(t)=\cos t \vec{i}+\sin t\vec{j}.

hint.p: Recall that in a vector equation \vec{r}(t) for a curve, the \vec{i} component is the x-coordinate, the \vec{j} component is the y-coordinate and where relevant, the \vec{k} component is the z-coordinate. Therefore, to compose we replace x, y and z with these components.

solution.p: The x coordinate of \vec{r}(t) is \cos t, and the y-coordinate is \sin t, so \vec{F} (\vec{r}(t)) =- \sin t \vec{i} + \cos t\vec{j}.

statement.p: Find \vec{F} (\vec{r}(t)) for \vec{F} (x,y)=-{30} y\vec{i} +{30} x\vec{j} and \vec{r}(t)=\cos t \vec{i}+\sin t\vec{j}\text{.}

hint.p: Recall that in a vector equation \vec{r}(t) for a curve, the \vec{i} component is the x-coordinate, the \vec{j} component is the y-coordinate and where relevant, the \vec{k} component is the z-coordinate. Therefore, to compose we replace x\text{,} y and z with these components.

solution.p: The x coordinate of \vec{r}(t) is \cos t\text{,} and the y-coordinate is \sin t\text{,} so \vec{F} (\vec{r}(t)) =-{30} \sin t \vec{i} + {30} \cos t\vec{j}\text{.}

statement.p: Find \vec{F} (\vec{r}(t)) for \vec{F} (x,y)=-xy\vec{i} +\sin x\vec{j} -z^2x\vec{k} and \vec{r}(t)= t \vec{i}+e^t\vec{j}-t^2\vec{k}.

hint.p: Recall that in a vector equation \vec{r}(t) for a curve, the \vec{i} component is the x-coordinate, the \vec{j} component is the y-coordinate and where relevant, the \vec{k} component is the z-coordinate. Therefore, to compose we replace x, y and z with these components.

solution.p: The x coordinate of \vec{r}(t) is t, the y-coordinate is e^t and the z-coordinate is -t^2, so \vec{F} (\vec{r}(t)) \amp =- te^t\vec{i} +\sin ( t) \vec{j} -(t^2)^2\cdot t\vec{k}\amp =- te^t\vec{i} +\sin ( t) \vec{j} - t^5\vec{k}.

statement.p: Find \vec{F} (\vec{r}(t)) for
and

hint.p: Recall that in a vector equation \vec{r}(t) for a curve, the \vec{i} component is the x-coordinate, the \vec{j} component is the y-coordinate and where relevant, the \vec{k} component is the z-coordinate. Therefore, to compose we replace x\text{,} y and z with these components.

solution.p: The x coordinate of \vec{r}(t) is {5} t\text{,} the y-coordinate is e^t and the z-coordinate is -t^2\text{,} so

####################################### ### Generated from PreTeXt source ### on 2019-03-08T15:04:05-05:00 ### ### https://pretextbook.org ### ####################################### ## DBsubject() ## DBchapter() ## DBsection() ## Level() ## KEYWORDS() ## TitleText1(Active Learning Worksheet) ## EditionText1() ## AuthorText1(Mathematics Consortium Working Group (MCWG)) ## Section1(not reported) ## Problem1(2.10) ## Author() ## Institution() ## Language(en-US)
DOCUMENT();
############################################################ # Load Macros ############################################################ loadMacros( "PGstandard.pl", "MathObjects.pl", "PGML.pl", "AnswerFormatHelp.pl", "PGcourse.pl", );
############################################################ # Header ############################################################ COMMENT('Authored in PreTeXt'); TEXT(beginproblem());
############################################################ # PG Setup ############################################################ $a = Compute(random(2,30,1));
Context("Vector"); Context()->variables->are(t=>"Real"); $ans=Vector(["-$a*te^t","sin($a*t)","-$a*t^5"]); $evaluatorforans=$ans->cmp(showCoordinateHints => 1);
############################################################ # Body ############################################################
BEGIN_PGML Find [`\vec{F} (\vec{r}(t))`] for
[```\vec{F} (x,y)=-xy\vec{i} +\sin x\vec{j} -z^2x\vec{k}```]
and
[```\vec{r}(t)=[$a] t \vec{i}+e^t\vec{j}-t^2\vec{k}\text{.}```]
[`\vec{F} (\vec{r}(t))=`] [_]{$evaluatorforans}{20} [@AnswerFormatHelp('vectors')@]*
END_PGML
############################################################ # Hint ############################################################ #Set value of $showHint in PGcourse.pl for course-wide attempt threshhold for revealing hints
BEGIN_PGML_HINT Recall that in a vector equation [`\vec{r}(t)`] for a curve, the [`\vec{i}`] component is the [`x`]-coordinate, the [`\vec{j}`] component is the [`y`]-coordinate and where relevant, the [`\vec{k}`] component is the [`z`]-coordinate. Therefore, to compose we replace [`x\text{,}`] [`y`] and [`z`] with these components.
END_PGML_HINT
############################################################ # Solution ############################################################
BEGIN_PGML_SOLUTION The [`x`] coordinate of [`\vec{r}(t)`] is [`[$a] t\text{,}`] the [`y`]-coordinate is [`e^t`] and the [`z`]-coordinate is [`-t^2\text{,}`] so
[```\newcommand{\amp}{&}\begin{aligned} \vec{F} (\vec{r}(t)) \amp =-[$a] te^t\vec{i} +\sin ([$a] t) \vec{j} -(t^2)^2\cdot [$a] t\vec{k}\\ \amp =-[$a] te^t\vec{i} +\sin ([$a] t) \vec{j} -[$a] t^5\vec{k}. \end{aligned}```]
END_PGML_SOLUTION
############################################################ # End Problem ############################################################
ENDDOCUMENT();

setup.pg-code: $a = Compute(random(2,30,1));

statement.p: Find \vec{r} (t) \cdot \vec{q} (t) for \vec{r}(t)=\sin ( t) \vec{i} +\cos ( t)\vec{j} and \vec{q}(t)=-\cos ( t) \vec{i} +\sin ( t)\vec{j}.

hint.p: Recall that the dot product of two vectors \vec{u} =a\vec{i} +b\vec{j} and \vec{v} =c\vec{i} +d\vec{j} is \vec{u} \cdot \vec{v}=ac+bd.

solution.p: We have \vec{r} (t) \cdot \vec{q} (t)\amp = (\sin ( t) \vec{i} +\cos ( t)\vec{j} )\cdot (-\cos ( t) \vec{i} +\sin ( t)\vec{j}) \amp = -\sin ( t) \cos ( t) +\cos ( t) \sin ( t) \amp = 0.

statement.p: Find \vec{r} (t) \cdot \vec{q} (t) for \vec{r}(t)=t \vec{i} +t^2\vec{j}+e^t\vec{k} and \vec{q}(t)=( +t) \vec{i} -t\vec{j}+( -t)\vec{k}.

hint.p: Recall that the dot product of two vectors \vec{u} =a\vec{i} +b\vec{j} and \vec{v} =c\vec{i} +d\vec{j} is \vec{u} \cdot \vec{v}=ac+bd.

solution.p: We have \vec{r} (t) \cdot \vec{q} (t)\amp = (t \vec{i} +t^2\vec{j}+e^t\vec{k})\cdot (( +t) \vec{i} -t\vec{j}+( -t)\vec{k}) \amp = t\cdot ( +t) +t^2\cdot (-t) +e^t\cdot ( -t) \amp = t + t^2 -t^3+$b e^t-te^t.

and

statement.p: Find the value of the integral. Give the exact answer or round to three decimal places.

hint.p: Break up the integral using the fact that the integral of a sum is the sum of the integrals.

webwork-reps.pg:
####################################### ### Generated from PreTeXt source ### on 2019-03-08T15:04:05-05:00 ### ### https://pretextbook.org ### ####################################### ## DBsubject() ## DBchapter() ## DBsection() ## Level() ## KEYWORDS() ## TitleText1(Active Learning Worksheet) ## EditionText1() ## AuthorText1(Mathematics Consortium Working Group (MCWG)) ## Section1(not reported) ## Problem1(2.13) ## Author() ## Institution() ## Language(en-US)
DOCUMENT();
############################################################ # Load Macros ############################################################ loadMacros( "PGstandard.pl", "MathObjects.pl", "PGML.pl", "AnswerFormatHelp.pl", "PGcourse.pl", );
############################################################ # Header ############################################################ COMMENT('Authored in PreTeXt'); TEXT(beginproblem());
############################################################ # PG Setup ############################################################ Context('Numeric'); $a=Compute(random(1,6,1)); $b=$a**2+2; $ans=Compute("sqrt($b)(3*e-2)/3");
############################################################ # Body ############################################################
BEGIN_PGML Find the value of the integral. Give the exact answer or round to three decimal places.
[`\displaystyle \int_{0}^{1} (e^x+x^2) \sqrt{[$b]} dx=`] [_]{$ans}{10} [@AnswerFormatHelp('numbers')@]*
END_PGML
############################################################ # Hint ############################################################ #Set value of $showHint in PGcourse.pl for course-wide attempt threshhold for revealing hints
BEGIN_PGML_HINT Break up the integral using the fact that the integral of a sum is the sum of the integrals.
END_PGML_HINT
############################################################ # Solution ############################################################
BEGIN_PGML_SOLUTION
[```\newcommand{\amp}{&}\begin{aligned} \int_{0}^{1} (e^x+x^2) \sqrt{[$b]} dx \amp = \sqrt{[$b]} \int_{0}^{1} e^x+ \sqrt{[$b]}\int_{0}^{1} x^2 dx\\ \amp = \sqrt{[$b]} \left( e^x\right)_{0}^{1} + \sqrt{[$b]}\left( \frac{x^3}{3} \right)_{0}^1 \\ \amp = \sqrt{[$b]} ( e-1) + \sqrt{[$b]}\left(\frac{1}{3} -0\right) \\ \amp = \frac{\sqrt{[$b]}}{3}(3e-2) \end{aligned}```]
END_PGML_SOLUTION
############################################################ # End Problem ############################################################
ENDDOCUMENT();

statement.p: Find the value of the integral. Give the exact answer or round to three decimal places.

hint.p: Break up the integral using the fact that the integral of a sum is the sum of the integrals.

webwork-reps.pg:
####################################### ### Generated from PreTeXt source ### on 2019-03-08T15:04:05-05:00 ### ### https://pretextbook.org ### ####################################### ## DBsubject() ## DBchapter() ## DBsection() ## Level() ## KEYWORDS() ## TitleText1(Active Learning Worksheet) ## EditionText1() ## AuthorText1(Mathematics Consortium Working Group (MCWG)) ## Section1(not reported) ## Problem1(2.14) ## Author() ## Institution() ## Language(en-US)
DOCUMENT();
############################################################ # Load Macros ############################################################ loadMacros( "PGstandard.pl", "MathObjects.pl", "PGML.pl", "AnswerFormatHelp.pl", "PGcourse.pl", );
############################################################ # Header ############################################################ COMMENT('Authored in PreTeXt'); TEXT(beginproblem());
############################################################ # PG Setup ############################################################ Context('Numeric'); $a=Compute(random(3,9,2)); $c=Compute(random(3,9,2)); $b=($a+$c)/2; $ans=$c/2;
############################################################ # Body ############################################################
BEGIN_PGML Find the value of the integral. Give the exact answer or round to three decimal places.
[`\displaystyle \int_0^1 -[$a] t+[$b] dt=`] [_]{$ans}{5} [@AnswerFormatHelp('numbers')@]*
END_PGML
############################################################ # Hint ############################################################ #Set value of $showHint in PGcourse.pl for course-wide attempt threshhold for revealing hints
BEGIN_PGML_HINT Break up the integral using the fact that the integral of a sum is the sum of the integrals.
END_PGML_HINT
############################################################ # Solution ############################################################
BEGIN_PGML_SOLUTION
[```\newcommand{\amp}{&}\begin{aligned} \int_{0}^{1} -[$a] t+[$b] dt \amp = -[$a] \int_{0}^{1} t dt + [$b] \int_{0}^{1} dt\\ \amp = -[$a] \left( \frac{t^2}{2} \right)_{0}^{1} + [$b] \left( t\right)_{0}^{1} \\ \amp = -[$a] \left( \frac{1}{2} -0\right) + [$b] \left( 1-0\right) \\ \amp = [$b]-\frac{[$a]}{2} = \frac{[$c]}{2}. \end{aligned}```]
END_PGML_SOLUTION
############################################################ # End Problem ############################################################
ENDDOCUMENT();

setup.pg-code: $a=Compute(random(3,19,2)); $ans=-$a/2;

statement.p: Find the value of the integral. Give the exact answer or round to three decimal places.

hint.p: Remember you can always take constants that are multiplying the whole integrand out of integral.

############################################################ # Body ############################################################
BEGIN_PGML Find the value of the integral. Give the exact answer or round to three decimal places.
[`\displaystyle \int_0^1 -[$a] t ~ dt=`] [_]{$ans}{5} [@AnswerFormatHelp('numbers')@]*
END_PGML
############################################################ # Hint ############################################################ #Set value of $showHint in PGcourse.pl for course-wide attempt threshhold for revealing hints
BEGIN_PGML_HINT Remember you can always take constants that are multiplying the whole integrand out of integral.
END_PGML_HINT
############################################################ # Solution ############################################################
BEGIN_PGML_SOLUTION
[``` \int_0^1 -[$a] t dt = -[$a]\int_0^1 t dt = -[$a]\left( \frac{t^2}{2} \right)_{0}^{1} =-\frac{[$a]}{2} ```]
END_PGML_SOLUTION
############################################################ # End Problem ############################################################
ENDDOCUMENT();

statement.p: Find the value of the integral. Give the exact answer or round to three decimal places.

hint.p: Break up the integral using the fact that the integral of a sum is the sum of the integrals.

statement.p: Find the value of the integral. Give the exact answer or round to three decimal places.

hint.p: Break up the integral using the fact that the integral of a sum is the sum of the integrals.

webwork-reps.pg:
####################################### ### Generated from PreTeXt source ### on 2019-03-08T15:04:05-05:00 ### ### https://pretextbook.org ### ####################################### ## DBsubject() ## DBchapter() ## DBsection() ## Level() ## KEYWORDS() ## TitleText1(Active Learning Worksheet) ## EditionText1() ## AuthorText1(Mathematics Consortium Working Group (MCWG)) ## Section1(not reported) ## Problem1(2.16) ## Author() ## Institution() ## Language(en-US)
DOCUMENT();
############################################################ # Load Macros ############################################################ loadMacros( "PGstandard.pl", "MathObjects.pl", "PGML.pl", "AnswerFormatHelp.pl", "PGcourse.pl", );
############################################################ # Header ############################################################ COMMENT('Authored in PreTeXt'); TEXT(beginproblem());
############################################################ # PG Setup ############################################################ Context('Numeric'); $a=Compute(random(2,4,2)); $aTwo=$a*2; $ans=Compute("(e^($aTwo)-1)/$a-8/3");
############################################################ # Body ############################################################
BEGIN_PGML Find the value of the integral. Give the exact answer or round to three decimal places.
[`\displaystyle \int_{-2}^{0} -t^2+e^{-[$a] t} ~ dt=`] [_]{$ans}{15} [@AnswerFormatHelp('numbers')@]*
END_PGML
############################################################ # Hint ############################################################ #Set value of $showHint in PGcourse.pl for course-wide attempt threshhold for revealing hints
BEGIN_PGML_HINT Break up the integral using the fact that the integral of a sum is the sum of the integrals.
END_PGML_HINT
############################################################ # Solution ############################################################
BEGIN_PGML_SOLUTION
[```\newcommand{\amp}{&}\begin{aligned} \int_{-2}^{0} -t^2+e^{-[$a] t} dt \amp = -\int_{-2}^{0} t^2 dt + \int_{-2}^{0} e^{-[$a] t} dt\\ \amp = \left( \frac{t^3}{3} \right)_{-2}^0 +\left(-\frac{e^{-[$a] t}}{[$a]} \right)_{-2}^0 \\ \amp = \left(0-\frac{8}{3}\right) + \left( -\frac{1}{2} -\left( -\frac{e^{[$aTwo]}}{[$a]} \right)\right)\\ \amp = -\frac{8}{3} + \frac{e^{[$aTwo]}-1}{[$a]} \end{aligned}```]
END_PGML_SOLUTION
############################################################ # End Problem ############################################################
ENDDOCUMENT();

statement.p: For the given vector field \vec{F} and curve C (oriented from left to right), determine whether \int_{C} \vec{F} \cdot d\vec{r} is positive, negative, or zero.
\int_{C} \vec{F} \cdot d\vec{r} is

hint.p: Recall that the integral \int_{C} \vec{F} \cdot d\vec{r} is a scalar measurement of how the vector field \vec{F} flows along the oriented curve C it is positive when it generally flows with the curve, negative when it flows against and zero when it is perpendicular or flows roughly equally with it and against it.

solution.p: In the second quadrant, the vector field flows roughly in the same direction as the curve, and in the first quadrant it flows perpendicular. Therefore the integral is positive.

solution.p: In the second quadrant, the vector field flows roughly in the same direction as the curve, and in the first quadrant it flows perpendicular. Therefore the integral is positive.

solution.p: In the second quadrant, the vector field flows perpendicular, and in the first quadrant it flows in the opposite direction as the curve. Therefore the integral is negative.

hint.p: Recall that the integral \int_{C} \vec{F} \cdot d\vec{r} is a scalar measurement of how the vector field \vec{F} flows along the oriented curve C it is positive when it generally flows with the curve, negative when it flows against and zero when it is perpendicular or flows roughly equally with it and against it.

solution.p: In the second quadrant, the vector field flows in the opposite direction, and in the first quadrant it flows in the same direction as the curve. Notice however that the amount of flow in each quadrant (positive and negative) are roughly equal, so the integral is zero.

statement.p: Evaluate \displaystyle \int_{C} \left( x\vec{i} -y\vec{j} \right) \cdot d\vec{r} where C is the line segment from (2,3) to (0,3).
The line segment from (2,3) to (0,3) can be parameterized by
\vec{r}(t)= for \leq t \leq .
Thus,

hint.p:
Parametrize the curve and remember that if \vec{r}(t), for a\leq t\leq b, is a smooth parameterization of an oriented curve C and \vec{F} is a vector field which is continuous on C, then
\int_C \vec{F}\cdot d\vec{r}=\int_a^b \vec{F}(\vec{r}(t))\cdot \vec{r}'(t) dt.

solution.p:
Remember that if \vec{r}(t), for a\leq t\leq b, is a smooth parameterization of an oriented curve C and \vec{F} is a vector field which is continuous on C, then
\int_C \vec{F}\cdot d\vec{r}=\int_a^b \vec{F}(\vec{r}(t))\cdot \vec{r}'(t) dt.
The line segment from (2,3) to (0,3) can be parameterized by
\vec{r}(t)=(-2t+2)\vec{i} +3\vec{j},\quad 0\leq t\leq 1
and we have
\vec{r}'(t)=-2\vec{i} .

Thus, \int_{C} \left( x\vec{i} -y\vec{j} \right) \cdot d\vec{r} \amp = \int_0^1 \left( (-2t+2)\vec{i}-3\vec{j}\right) \cdot \left(-2\vec{i} \right)dt\amp = \int_0^1 4t-4 dt \amp = \left( 2t^2-4t\right)_{0}^{1} \amp = -2.

statement.p: Evaluate \displaystyle \int_{C} \left( z\vec{i} -y\vec{j}+x\vec{k} \right) \cdot d\vec{r} where C is the line segment from (5,0,2) to (5,3,4).
The line segment from (5,0,2) to (5,3,4) can be parameterized by
\vec{r}(t)= for \leq t \leq .
Thus,

hint.p:
Parametrize the curve and remember that if \vec{r}(t), for a\leq t\leq b, is a smooth parameterization of an oriented curve C and \vec{F} is a vector field which is continuous on C, then
\int_C \vec{F}\cdot d\vec{r}=\int_a^b \vec{F}(\vec{r}(t))\cdot \vec{r}'(t) dt.

solution.p:
Remember that if \vec{r}(t), for a\leq t\leq b, is a smooth parameterization of an oriented curve C and \vec{F} is a vector field which is continuous on C, then
\int_C \vec{F}\cdot d\vec{r}=\int_a^b \vec{F}(\vec{r}(t))\cdot \vec{r}'(t) dt.

The line segment from (5,0,2) to (5,3,4) can be parameterized by
\vec{r}(t)=5\vec{i} +3t\vec{j}+(2t+2)\vec{k},\quad 0\leq t\leq 1
and we have
\vec{r}'(t)=3\vec{j} +2\vec{k}.

Thus, \int_{C} \left( z\vec{i} -y\vec{j}+x\vec{k} \right) \cdot d\vec{r} \amp = \int_0^1 \left( (2t+2)\vec{i}-3t\vec{j}+5\vec{k}\right) \cdot \left(3\vec{j}+2\vec{k} \right)dt\amp = \int_0^1 (-9t+10) dt \amp = \left( -\frac{9t^2}{2}+10t\right)_{0}^{1} \amp = 5.5.

statement.p: Evaluate \displaystyle \int_{C} \left(x^2\vec{i} - y\vec{j} \right) \cdot d\vec{r} where C is the curve y=e^x from (2,e^2) to (0,1).
The curve y=e^x from (2,e^2) to (0,1) can be parameterized by \vec{r}(t)= x(t) \vec{i} + y(t) \vec{j} where
for \leq t \leq .
Thus,

hint.p:
Parametrize the curve and remember that if \vec{r}(t), for a\leq t\leq b, is a smooth parameterization of an oriented curve C and \vec{F} is a vector field which is continuous on C, then
\int_C \vec{F}\cdot d\vec{r}=\int_a^b \vec{F}(\vec{r}(t))\cdot \vec{r}'(t) dt.

solution.p:
Remember that if \vec{r}(t), for a\leq t\leq b, is a smooth parameterization of an oriented curve C and \vec{F} is a vector field which is continuous on C, then
\int_C \vec{F}\cdot d\vec{r}=\int_a^b \vec{F}(\vec{r}(t))\cdot \vec{r}'(t) dt.

The curve y=e^x from (0,1) to (2,e^2) can be parameterized by t\vec{i}+(e^{t})\vec{j} with 0\leq t\leq 2. To find a parameterization from (2,e^2) to (0,1) we reverse the orientation by replacing t by -t. Thus, the curve y=e^x from (2,e^2) to (0,1) can be parameterized by
\vec{r}(t)=-t\vec{i}+(e^{-t})\vec{j},\quad -2\leq t\leq 0,
and we have
\vec{r}'(t)=-\vec{i} -e^{-t}\vec{j}.

Thus \int_{C} \left( x^2\vec{i} - y\vec{j} \right) \cdot d\vec{r} \amp = \int_{-2}^{0} \left( (-t)^2\vec{i}-(e^{-t})\vec{j}\right) \cdot \left(-\vec{i}-e^{-t}\vec{j} \right)dt \amp = \int_{-2}^{0} -t^2+e^{-2t} dt \amp = \left( -\frac{t^3}{3}-\frac{e^{-2t}}{2}\right)_{-2}^0 \amp = \left( 0-\frac{e^{0}}{2}\right)-\left( -\frac{(-2)^3}{3}-\frac{e^{4}}{2}\right) \amp = \frac{1}{6}(3 e^4 - 19)\approx 24.132.

solution.p: Remember that if \vec{r}(t)\text{,} for a\leq t\leq b\text{,} is a smooth parameterization of an oriented curve C and \vec{F} is a vector field which is continuous on C\text{,} then

The curve y=e^x from (0,1) to (2,e^2) can be parameterized by t\vec{i}+(e^{t})\vec{j} with 0\leq t\leq 2\text{.} To find a parameterization from (2,e^2) to (0,1) we reverse the orientation by replacing t by -t\text{.} Thus, the curve y=e^x from (2,e^2) to (0,1) can be parameterized by

statement.p: Evaluate \displaystyle \int_{C} \left( \vec{i} -y\vec{j} \right) \cdot d\vec{r} where C is the part of the circle of radius 3 centered at the origin in the first quadrant from from (3,0) to (0,3).
The curve C can be parameterized by \vec{r}(t)= x(t) \vec{i} + y(t) \vec{j} where
for \leq t \leq .
Thus,

hint.p:
Parametrize the curve and remember that if \vec{r}(t), for a\leq t\leq b, is a smooth parameterization of an oriented curve C and \vec{F} is a vector field which is continuous on C, then
\int_C \vec{F}\cdot d\vec{r}=\int_a^b \vec{F}(\vec{r}(t))\cdot \vec{r}'(t) dt.

solution.p:
Remember that if \vec{r}(t), for a\leq t\leq b, is a smooth parameterization of an oriented curve C and \vec{F} is a vector field which is continuous on C, then
\int_C \vec{F}\cdot d\vec{r}=\int_a^b \vec{F}(\vec{r}(t))\cdot \vec{r}'(t) dt.

The part of the circle of radius 3 centered at the origin in the first quadrant from from (3,0) to (0,3) can be parameterized by
\vec{r}(t)=3\cos(t)\vec{i}+3\sin(t)\vec{j},\quad 0\leq t\leq \pi/2,
and so we have
\vec{r}'(t)=-3\sin(t)\vec{i}+3\cos(t)\vec{j}.

Thus, \int_{C} \left( \vec{i} -y\vec{j} \right) \cdot d\vec{r} \amp = \int_{0}^{\pi/2} \left( \vec{i}-3\sin(t)\vec{j}\right) \cdot \left(-3\sin(t)\vec{i}+3\cos(t)\vec{j} \right)dt\amp = \int_{0}^{\pi/2} \left(-3\sin(t)-9\sin(t)\cos(t) \right) dt \amp = \left( 3\cos{(t)} -\frac{9}{2} \sin^2{(t)}\right)_{0}^{\pi /2} \amp = \left( 0 -\frac{9}{2} \right)-\left( 3 -0\right) \amp = -7.5

statement.p: Evaluate \displaystyle \int_{C} \left( y\vec{i} +2x\vec{j} \right) \cdot d\vec{r} where C is the curve x=\cos{(y)} from (1,2\pi ) to (1,0).
The curve C can be parameterized by \vec{r}(t)= x(t) \vec{i} + y(t) \vec{j} where
for \leq t \leq .
Thus,

hint.p:
Parametrize the curve and remember that if \vec{r}(t), for a\leq t\leq b, is a smooth parameterization of an oriented curve C and \vec{F} is a vector field which is continuous on C, then
\int_C \vec{F}\cdot d\vec{r}=\int_a^b \vec{F}(\vec{r}(t))\cdot \vec{r}'(t) dt.

solution.p:
Remember that if \vec{r}(t), for a\leq t\leq b, is a smooth parameterization of an oriented curve C and \vec{F} is a vector field which is continuous on C, then
\int_C \vec{F}\cdot d\vec{r}=\int_a^b \vec{F}(\vec{r}(t))\cdot \vec{r}'(t) dt.

The curve x=\cos{(y)} from (1,0) to (1,2\pi) can be parameterized by \cos(t)\vec{i}+t\vec{j} with 0\leq t\leq 2\pi. To find a parameterization from (1,2\pi) to (1,0) we reverse the orientation by replacing t by -t. Thus, the curve x=\cos{(y)} from (1,2\pi) to (1,0) can be parameterized by
\vec{r}(t)=\cos(t)\vec{i}-t\vec{j},\quad -2\pi\leq t\leq 0,
(since \cos(-t)=\cos(t)), and we have
\vec{r}'(t)=-\sin(t)\vec{i}-\vec{j}.

Thus, \int_{C} \left(y\vec{i} +2x\vec{j} \right) \cdot d\vec{r} \amp = \int_{-2\pi}^{0} \left( -t\vec{i}+2\cos(t)\vec{j}\right) \cdot \left(-\sin(t)\vec{i}-\vec{j} \right)dt\amp = \int_{-2\pi}^{0} \left( t\sin(t)-2\cos(t) \right) dt \amp = \left(\sin{(t)} -t\cos{(t)} -2\sin(t)\right)_{-2\pi }^{0} \amp = 0-\left(0 -(-2\pi)-0\right) \amp = -2\pi

setup.pg-code: $ans=Compute("2,3,4,5"); $evalforans=$ans->cmp(showLengthHints => 1);

authored.statement:
Which of the following parameterizations describes the quarter circle in the figure?
(\cos t, \sin t), \ 0\leq t\leq\frac{\pi}{2}
(\sin t, \cos t), \ 0\leq t\leq\frac{\pi}{2}
(-\cos t, \sin t), \ \frac{\pi}{2}\leq t\leq \pi
(\cos t, -\sin t), \ \frac{3\pi}{2}\leq t\leq 2\pi
(\cos t, -\sin t), \ -\frac{\pi}{2}\leq t\leq 0
Enter all correct answers as a list in the response field below (list the corresponding numbers)
authored.solution: Choices 2, 3, 4, 5 describe the quarter circle in the figure. All except choice 1 trace the given quarter circle in the correct direction.

statement.p: Enter all correct answers as a list in the response field below (list the corresponding numbers)

solution.p: Choices 2, 3, 4, 5 describe the quarter circle in the figure. All except choice 1 trace the given quarter circle in the correct direction.

####################################### ### Generated from PreTeXt source ### on 2019-03-08T15:04:05-05:00 ### ### https://pretextbook.org ### ####################################### ## DBsubject() ## DBchapter() ## DBsection() ## Level() ## KEYWORDS() ## TitleText1(Active Learning Worksheet) ## EditionText1() ## AuthorText1(Mathematics Consortium Working Group (MCWG)) ## Section1(not reported) ## Problem1(4.1) ## Author() ## Institution() ## Language(en-US)
DOCUMENT();
############################################################ # Load Macros ############################################################ loadMacros( "PGstandard.pl", "MathObjects.pl", "PGML.pl", "AnswerFormatHelp.pl", "PGcourse.pl", );
############################################################ # Header ############################################################ COMMENT('Authored in PreTeXt'); TEXT(beginproblem());
############################################################ # PG Setup ############################################################ Context('Numeric'); $ans=Compute("2,3,4,5"); $evalforans=$ans->cmp(showLengthHints => 1);
############################################################ # Body ############################################################
BEGIN_PGML Which of the following parameterizations describes the quarter circle in the figure? 1. [`(\cos t, \sin t), \ 0\leq t\leq\frac{\pi}{2}`] 1. [`(\sin t, \cos t), \ 0\leq t\leq\frac{\pi}{2}`] 1. [`(-\cos t, \sin t), \ \frac{\pi}{2}\leq t\leq \pi`] 1. [`(\cos t, -\sin t), \ \frac{3\pi}{2}\leq t\leq 2\pi`] 1. [`(\cos t, -\sin t), \ -\frac{\pi}{2}\leq t\leq 0`]
Enter all correct answers as a list in the response field below (list the corresponding numbers)
[_]{$evalforans}{15} [@AnswerFormatHelp('numbers')@]*
END_PGML
############################################################ # Hint ############################################################ #Set value of $showHint in PGcourse.pl for course-wide attempt threshhold for revealing hints
BEGIN_PGML_HINT
END_PGML_HINT
############################################################ # Solution ############################################################
BEGIN_PGML_SOLUTION Choices 2, 3, 4, 5 describe the quarter circle in the figure. All except choice 1 trace the given quarter circle in the correct direction. END_PGML_SOLUTION
############################################################ # End Problem ############################################################
ENDDOCUMENT();

statement.p:
If a is increased, which of the following are correct?
the radius of the circle increases.
the speed of the particle increases.
the center of the circle changes.
the path ceases to be a circle.
List the numbers of all correct choices:

stage.solution: Choice 2. The speed of the particle increases. As a increases, it takes less time for the particle to complete one revolution, thus the speed increases.

statement.p: Suppose the particle's movement is described by (\cos t, \sin t). Which values of a in (\cos at, \sin at) would represent a decrease in speed for the particle?
Open ended question (no response field).
How can you modify the formulas to change the radius and the center of the circle? To make the particle circle in the opposite direction?
